Petition of Antônio de Melo e Albuquerque to the General-in-Chief

Most Illustrious and Excellent Sir General-in-Chief

The honorary Colonel Antônio de Melo e Albuquerque states that he, the Petitioner, after performing the services proven by the documents numbered 1 to 8 (which he implores Your Excellency to consider) Passo Fundo (brigade assembled and created by the Petitioner) and having obtained from the Most Excellent Sir Labatut permission to go to his house in the village of Cruz Alta, adjacent to the same place, was granted this, and soon after, during the same days of the Petitioner’s march, by an order of the day of that general dated December 8, 1840, the brigade under the Petitioner’s command was dissolved, a corps was formed from it, without giving any position to the Petitioner, nor was the slightest blame attributed to him! The Petitioner was taken by surprise at such conduct, emanating from ridiculous intrigues plotted by cowardly envious persons; and seeing that he no longer had a position in that division, he proceeded to this place and presented himself successively not only to the Most Excellent Sir Alvares Machado, but also to the current Most Excellent President and to Your Excellency, Your Excellency, Your Excellency Cima da Serra, and to promote there a new reaction, which Your Excellency, Most Excellent Sir, Most Excellent Sir, Your Excellency, December 9, 1840 until March 17, 1842, in which by Your Excellency

Petitions to Your Excellency

Hopes to Receive Mercy Porto Alegre, May 24, 1842. Antônio de Melo e Albuquerque Honorary Colonel

Report to the Military Box, General Headquarters in Porto Alegre, May 24, 1842. Count of Rio Pardo.
